Card Name: Soil management and sustainability
Hazard characterization: Chemical Exposure  Pesticides and Herbicides: Overuse of chemical fertilizers and pesticides can lead to residues on food products, posing health risks to consumers and farmworkers, including acute poisoning and long-term health issues such as cancer and endocrine disruption.  Nutrient Runoff: Excessive nutrient runoff from poorly managed soils can contaminate water supplies with nitrates and phosphates, leading to waterborne diseases and other health problems.  2. Foodborne Illness  Pathogen Contamination: Soil health affects the prevalence of pathogens like E. coli and Salmonella. Poor soil management can increase the risk of contamination, leading to foodborne illnesses when crops are consumed.  3. Respiratory Issues  Dust and Particulate Matter: Poor soil management practices can lead to increased soil erosion and airborne dust, which can cause respiratory problems for farmworkers and nearby communities.  4. Nutritional Deficiencies  Soil Degradation: Degraded soils often yield crops with lower nutritional value. This can contribute to deficiencies in essential vitamins and minerals in populations that rely heavily on those crops for their diets.  5. Ecosystem Health Impact  Biodiversity Loss: Unsustainable soil practices can lead to a decline in biodiversity, which can disrupt ecosystem services such as pollination and natural pest control, potentially leading to increased pesticide use and its associated health risks.  6. Climate Change Effects  Increased Food Insecurity: Climate change exacerbates food risk, leading to more unpredictable food supply and quality. Food insecurity can result in malnutrition and a host of related health issues.  7. Mental Health Concerns  Stress from Food Insecurity: Communities affected by soil mismanagement and the resulting food scarcity may experience increased anxiety and mental health issues related to food insecurity.

Card Name: Anti-cholesterol supplements, the European Commission intervenes: “Limit the dosages, they can give side effects”
Hazard characterization: Side Effects: Monacolin and lovastatin share the same side effects, which include:    Muscle pain and weakness (myopathy)  Liver damage  Headaches  Gastrointestinal issues  Skin reactions  Problems affecting connective tissue and the nervous system    Lack of Medical Supervision: Since these supplements are available without a prescription, consumers may not receive the necessary medical guidance to identify and manage potential side effects or interactions with other medications.    Dosage Risks: Without regulation, consumers might inadvertently consume doses higher than recommended, increasing the risk of adverse effects. The new regulation aims to mitigate this by limiting daily intake to under 3 mg of monacolin.    Interactions with Other Medications: Monacolin can interact with other drugs, potentially leading to harmful effects, which might not be monitored without medical oversight.    Quality and Consistency: Supplements can vary in monacolin content, leading to inconsistent dosing and effectiveness, unlike prescription medications which have strict quality controls.    The European Commission’s regulation emphasizes the importance of consumer awareness and the need for caution when using these supplements, highlighting the necessity of consulting healthcare professionals.

Card Name: Influenza D virus in cattle and pigs
Hazard characterization: A putative new influenza virus related to genus D has been isolated in pigs and cattle in the USA, but has also appeared in cattle in France. The new virus is capable of infecting pigs and cattle, as well as replicating and spreading efficiently in ferrets - this was used for the animal model in which the spread of influenza was studied, so it can be assumed that it can also infect humans. Positive hemagglutination inhibition tests were also found in the North American population, but due to the few positive samples and other reasons, the presence of the influenza D virus in the human population is not yet clear.  Influenza is detected in animals using the PCR method based on the type A virus, which is therefore currently not suitable for detecting the type D of influenza. Method developments of this nature are underway.  Further investigation is required to reveal the range of host organisms and carrier species, as well as the specific role they play in the appearance of respiratory clinical symptoms observed in cattle, and the public health relevance of the presumed new virus must also be evaluated.
Pre-screening: It will move on to PHASE I
1. Justification of FILTERING: First in the US in 2011, in pigs, then in cattle. More recent cases were in France and China. The pathogen has recently been discovered and an intercontinental spread of the pathogen is expected, with the potential to spread to European livestock populations.
